events.name: Android Wear and Google IO re-cap
events.description:
Summer is almost over and we need to get back to work and fix support for all the new stuff that Google announced for Android over the summer. In this first meetup for the season we will hear an introduction to Android Wear and a general re-cap of what was announced at Google IO.

Getting started with Wear - Henrik Sandström
The goal of this talk is to understand what Android Wear is about. What can and can't it do? How do we put apps on it? We will go through how to create an app and how a watch talks to your phone.

Google IO re-cap
We will go through the major highlights for Android that was announced at Google IO. This session will be a fairly open thing where we hope the audience can share their thought and experiences.

events.name: DroidCamp 2014
events.description:
Welcome to the second DroidCamp following directly after the two day DroidCon in October. Please note that this is not the place to register for the awesome Hackathon that is also organized the same day in the same building.

DroidCamp is an open, free, participatory event. It doesn't matter if you are an experienced developer, designer or just bought your first Android device. Anyone can come. There is no audience, only participants. The whole idea is to get all kinds of Android people together to collaborate, network and learn.

There will be several rooms available for presentations and discussions. We welcome presentations in both English and Swedish, but we will try to make sure that every time slot will include at least one session in English.

The day starts with everyone suggesting their sessions followed by a simple democratic voting session to set the agenda of the day.

We're still looking for more sponsors for the event, so please contact us if you want to contribute and have your company name visible at the event.
events.how_to_find_us: Just use the main entrance of the Nod house

events.name: Android Meetup At Bontouch
events.description:
18.00 Doors Opened & Welcome to Bontouch

• Getting started with cardboard development, Nicklas Ansman – Bontouch

• App Clinic!
We plan to do an App Clinic where we bring up selected Android apps and discuss their strengths and weaknesses. We will post a poll where you can vote on which apps we will talk about later on. Meanwhile, we suggest that you have a look at the App Clinic show with Reto Meier and Ian Ni-Lewis.

This meet is hosted by Bontouch

events.name: Android Meetup at Viaplay
events.description:
Welcome!

Viaplay is buying food / beer & soft drinks for everyone, so please RSVP to this event and let them know if you're coming. All attendees must be registered (no guests) and have a RSVP. Specify if you prefer vegetarian food or have any allergies. Bring photo id to the meet to be sure to be let in.

Schedule

18.00 Doors opens
18.30 Presentations starts

Speakers / Topics

Getting started with the Chromecast SDK for Android - Olle Pettersson
 A walk trough of the fundamental concepts on how Chromecast and the MediaRouter framework in Android works. We will also look at how to add support for Chromecast in your app and start casting videos.

Google Developer Expert summit  - Erik Hellman 
Learn about all the latest technologies and tools from Google around the Android eco-system. I'll try to cover as much as possible, including Android TV, Google Cloud integration and the latest news about Lollipop.

events.name: Android Meetup at Truecaller
events.description:
Welcome!

This time we'll be hosted by Truecaller.

Truecaller is buying food, beer & soft drinks for everyone, so please RSVP and let us know if you're coming. Please specify if you prefer vegetarian food or have any allergies.


Schedule

18.00 Doors opens 
18.30 Presentations starts

Speakers / Topics

SQLite, Ola Rende (Citerus)

Android data persistence is enabled by the marvelous piece of software known as SQLite. In this talk, we will take a look at some of the database manager's good parts, bad parts and downright weird parts as well as how to leverage SQLite for performance and ease of testing.

Adapting Truecaller to Material Design, Sergio Cucinella (Truecaller)

Sergio will talk about the work and challenges they had when implementing material design in Truecaller.

events.name: Android TV Meetup at Google
events.description:
Welcome to Google!

This meetup is about Android TV.

Agenda

Welcome & Introduction to Android TV
Robert Nyman

How to build apps for Android TV
Erik Hellman

Demos
We will have couple of Android TV devices available for you to try.

events.name: Android Meetup at King
events.description:
Time for the first Android Meetup STHLM after the summer vacations! This time we will be at the office of King at Sveavägen 44. Food and drinks will be served, starting at 17.00.

The schedule (so far) for this event is as follows.

17:15 - Introduction and Announcements
Erik Hellman

17:20 - Welcome to King
King HR

17:30 - Android NDK for multi-platform apps and games
Carlos Jiménez Rams, King

18:00 - Current state of Android - from Google IO until now
Erik Hellman

events.name: Android Unconference
events.description:
Following this years DroidCon Stockholm we will arrange a full day Unconference on all things Android. 

I hope you're all well and getting ready for the Android Unconference this weekend. First of all, if you have RSVPed yes and got a place but already know that you won't be able to make it, please update your response so that someone on the waiting list can get your place instead.

Please not that this is an unconference event and not a regular meetup. It will go on for a full day (or until the last person leaves) and we hope to see lots of cool presentations and hear interesting discussions. While it is not required that you do a presentation yourself, we do expect everyone to participate actively.

The event will be hosted at the co-working space THINGS at the KTH Campus (see http://www.thingstock...­) and we will be serving lunch (Pizza!) and provide some beers as well. We will have access to two separate rooms with a projector in each. The event will start with a planing session where everyone can suggest their own presentation and we will decide on the schedule together. We will bring Post-Its and pens as well as converters for the projectors. There will also be a WiFi available at the event.

To make this a bit more exciting, Google has provided us with a few gifts. The plan is to use these as awards for the best sessions or demos, all which will be decided by the participants. We currently have an LG Watch urbane (Android Wear), two Nexus Players (Android TV), Chromecast, Google Cardboards and a couple of Bluetooth beacons compatible with Android Nearby and Eddystone. While we do plan to give these away by the end of the day, we would also like to see people use them for their presentations and demos if possible.

If you have any questions regarding the event, please don't hesitate to contact us.

Finally, we also hope to see you at the DroidCon event starting this Thursday. There are still tickets left and you can find all the information and the speaker lineup at http://droidcon.se/events/stockholm-2015/

Looking forward to seeing you all soon!

Best Regards,
Erik, Johan, Adam and Peter

events.name: Android Meetup at Magine with Corey Latislaw
events.description:
Welcome to Magine!

Food & drinks will be served, please let us know if you have any culinary preferences.

Schedule

18.00 Doors opens

18.15 Welcome & announcements

18.30 Android TV in practice.
Jonas from Magine TV will share some experiences from porting the Magine app to Android TV (and also Amazon Fire TV) and give some tips and tricks on how you can adopt your current app to Android TV or getting started with a new one. https://magine.com

19.00 Break

19.30 Corey Latislaw
Corey is visiting us on her route between DroidCon Moscow, Øredev & DroidCon London. She has agreed to come to Android Meetup STHLM and present for us as well. http://coreylatislaw.com/

Android is the World Phone
Android is the most popular operating system in the world and is used by billions of people! This presents unprecedented opportunity in emerging markets to make a positive impact on people's lives.

You will explore emerging use cases across such diverse sectors as agriculture, banking, activism, and healthcare. You will walk away with a deeper appreciation for the technical and social challenges you will encounter in these markets and practical mitigations to overcome them to make a difference.

How will you impact the next billion?

Please keep your RSVP up to date so we know how many to expect.

Welcome!
Johan, Erik & Jonas

events.name: Christmas Special: Android Meetup @ iZettle
events.description:
It is time for the final Android Meetup Stockholm for 2015! This time we will be hosted by iZettle in their office at Jakobsbergsgatan 31. 

We now have an agenda for the evening. Starting times for each session is approximate. We plan to keep each talk to 30 minutes so we get some nice breaks to mingle. 

17:15 - Introduction

17:30 - How does iZettle do payment in Android, Jianing Zhang and Christoffer Lindfors

18:45 - iZettle approach to Android Design, Sofia Carlander

19:30 - RxJava for Android Explained, Erik Hellman

See you all there!

P.S. As usual, please update your RSVP in case you know you can't make it! D.S.

events.name: Android Meetup at JFokus
events.description:
Welcome to the first meetup of 2016, this time we will be hosted by JFokus at Stockholm Waterfront Congress Center. We will be in Room C4 on level 2.

Food and drinks will be available and after the meetup we're welcome to join the ongoing conference party.

From Mattias, JFokus: 

Its important that you don't show up too early for this meetup. Jfokus session ends at 18.00 and attendees need to exit the rooms and leave to avoid "strul". If you come earlier, the hotel have a bar in the reception for a "after-work-beer" while waiting.

You should enter the venue in the "canyon" between the hotel and the Waterfront Congress Centre. Walk directly down to the rooms at level 2. There will be coat-hangers in the rooms instead of using the Waterfront cloakroom.

For people at waiting list... We have room for more people, but all food is already ordered. I think we can host up to 80 people, if the last 20 eat before they come to the meetup rather the eating the wrap we offer.

Agenda

18.30 Welcome & Mingle

19.00 Amira Lakhal (Valtech) "IOT, Timeseries and prediction with Android, Cassandra and Spark"

~20.00 Hans Dockter (Gradleware) "Deep Dive Into the Gradle-Based Android Build System"

~21.00 Joining the conference party

Presentations

Amira Lakhal (Valtech)

"IOT, Timeseries and prediction with Android, Cassandra and Spark"

IOT has a massive potential and its impact in our daily life is important. Here is an exemple of using a connected object and analysing its data: we'll see how to collect data using the accelerometer sensor of your smartphone. Then, we'll store it in Cassandra as a Timeseries model. Finally, we'll analyse those data and predict the activity with Spark. We will see a live demo on stage to show this solution working in realtime.

Hans Dockter (Gradleware)

"Deep Dive Into the Gradle-Based Android Build System"

This talk will provide an in-depth tour of the new Android buildsystem, which is designed to elegantly deal with the diversity of theAndroid ecosystem and the demands of modern development practices. We will go through its concepts and features such as variant support and the latest performance improvements.

The new build system is also key component to the Android Studio. We will show how this makes Android Studio much more powerful than otherIDEs. We'll also discuss how the build system can be leveraged to build powerful CI solutions and how to integrate it into large renterprise build processes.

We will give a sneak preview of a new major version of the GradleAndroid plugin, which comes with another massive boost for performance and variant aware dependency management.


"App Demos & Reviews"

If you want to demo or have your app reviewed, please submit this form, http://goo.gl/forms/PYlq63tbw1

events.name: Android Meetup at Apegroup
events.description:
It is time for another Android Meetup and this time we are thrilled to be hosted by Apegroup! For this event we have an international speaker coming from Genymotion; Eyal Lezmy will join us and speak about Gradle Plugins.

For this event we will open the RSVP one week before (on 8th of March, 11am). The reason is that we want to avoid lots of late RSVP updates and no-shows. 

Agenda:

17:00
Doors open, food and drinks served

17:30 - 17:50
Introductions by Apegroup

18:00 - 18:40
"Behavior-Driven Development for Android" by Miguel Á. Domínguez Coloma from Betsson Group

As developers we develop scalable, optimized and bug-free Android applications. We can use different code coverage methodologies and technologies to prove that our code is right.

But, is our code doing the right thing?

This talk is about technology and business. Using Behavior-driven development will help us to develop the right product aligned with business interests.

We will cover from the Gherkin language, to the implementation using JavaScript to automate our tests and reports. Everything for Android using Appium!

Do the right thing in the right way! 

18:50 - 19:30
"Gradle plugins, take it to the next level" by Eyal LEZMY from Genymotion
It's now a long time Gradle is the official build system for Android. And as a very good developer you already switched to it, and you customize it depending on your needs. Most of the time, the cleaner way to manage all these customizations is to build Gradle plugins. During this talk you will discover best practices about building your plugin to make it a good citizen, more efficient, and more famous! This presentation will tell about: 
- Building a Gradly DSL 
- Interact with the Android Gradle Plugin 
- Test your project on the good way

events.name: Android Meetup at Screen Interaction
events.description:
Welcome to a new Android Meetup, we're excited to be hosted by Screen Interaction. Screen Interaction does not only provide a great space with a fantastic view from the 29th floor, food & drinks for everyone but also covers the cost for flying in Christopher Jenkins author of Calligraphy from London to us.

We'll have a great agenda planned for you with deep dive into fonts and architecture for modern Android apps.

Please note that we will open the RSVP one week before (Thursday, April 21  10.00).

Agenda
17.30 Doors open
18.00 Welcome
~18.15 Presentation 1
~19.00 Paus
~19.15 Presentation 2
~19.45 Paus
~20.00 Presentation 3

Speakers

Actually using Typefaces in your Apps.
Christopher Jenkins (Guest speaker from London)

We all want to design beautiful Apps. Whilst the guidelines have dramatically improved for designing layouts, UI components and styling. Applying Typefaces has been neglected and doesn't seem to be improving anytime soon.

We shall explore some methods to make applying Typefaces to your App easier, consistent and hopefully remove some unnecessary headaches.

Designing fonts for screen legibility
Kristian Möller (Type Designer from Stockholm)

Once you manage to install a custom font in your app – how do you know its good?

The font is usually the smallest element in any design system. The letter shape dictates the overall feel and sentiment of every application where it’s used. As for design and layout, a font is made for a key purpose, and can’t fit all needs at the same time, (that’s why more than one is usually needed).

Since commercial font licenses for application can be very expensive, and the font software is often made for general use, rather than your applications needs, maybe it’s time to design or commission your own?

This keynote will take you trough the choices and many aspects of type design in 2016.

Architecting Modern Android Apps
Samuel Wejéus (Screen Interaction)

When asked about architecture of their app most people answer that they use either fragments or activities. But is that really the correct level of abstraction? What about internal app architecture? Should we really let the framework dictate how we architect our applications?

This is a story of how we rose from chaos by ignoring Android conventions and migrated to use-case driven architecture. This presentation will be about the EBI architecture (entities, boundaries and interactors) and model, view, presenters (MVP).

If you have any questions don't hesitate to contact us.

events.name: Android Meetup at HiQ with Lyft
events.description:
Welcome to HiQ!

Wraps & drinks will be served, please let us know if you have any culinary preferences (allergies, vegetarian etc) at least two days before the event.

For this event we're happy let you know that Lyft will be visiting us, you don't want to miss this one.

Erik Hellman will give a revisited version of his talk he did at DroidCon Berlin about Bluetooth Low Energy.

Note: RSVP for this event opens September 7th 10.00 am.

Schedule

17.00 Doors opens and food

17.30 Introduction

17.45 Sebastian Brannstrom, Lyft

~18.45 Erik Hellman

Speakers

Peak mobile or productive plateau? Mobile at scale at Lyft.

Sebastian Brannstrom, Lyft

At Lyft we build apps at scale. Today, a team of over 40 people spread across a dozen teams push out new versions of our apps for iPhone and Android on a weekly basis. But it wasn't always like this. I'll talk about how we got from our humble beginnings with a pair of engineers back in 2012 to the machine that we have today. 

While we have good reasons to be proud of where we are, plenty of mistakes were made along the way. We had to try many tools and processes to find what worked for us at the time, and to set ourselves up for success in the future.

Just as Lyft and the industry has reached this plateau of productivity, new exciting things are on the horizon. Smart digital assistants, chat bots and new web technologies are challenging the app as the default platform. Have we perhaps reached peak mobile?

Sebastian is originally from Stockholm. He has been programming since his teens. He fell into mobile in 2006 when he got his first Symbian phone. It couldn't do podcasts, so he wrote an app for that and open sourced it. He was then hired by Symbian and moved to London. After leaving Symbian, Sebastian was employee #11 at Lyft. He wrote the first iteration of the Lyft app as a Hackathon project in 2012. After overseeing the mobile team for three years, he moved into a new role leading the engineering efforts for autonomous software. Now he spends his time sorting out paperwork for his new home in San Francisco and threatening to move to the second Lyft engineering office in Seattle. Sebastian is currently at Burning man, which is why Alex wrote his bio. We hope he finds himself but doesn't lose his voice! 

Practical Bluetooth LE

Erik Hellman

Bluetooth Low Energy was announced for Android 4.3 (Jelly Bean MR2, API level 18) and the API has received some updates with each new version since then. Unfortunately, the way the API works and the number of undocumented "features" in the Bluetooth stack on Android has made it very difficult to work with. Regardless if you're doing something simple like scanning for beacons or doing two-way communication with another device, you're bound to run into problems that can be both hard to identify and difficult to fix.

In this talk we will go through the most common pitfalls regarding Bluetooth LE on Android and how to deal with them. You'll learn how to properly scan for devices, connect to them, and exchange data.

Welcome!

events.name: Android Meetup with Realm and Microsoft at Foo Café Stockholm
events.description:
We're thrilled to announce our first Android Meetup in cooperation with Foo Café Stockholm. Our sponsor is Microsoft and we will also have Christian Melchior from Realm. 

Important information: To sign up for this event you need to register your RSVP at http://www.foocafe.org/stockholm/events/1274-how-you-can-use-xamarin-test-cloud-to-test-your-android-apps. 

17.30 - Doors open (Note that doors will be locked at 18.00. Arrive before!)

17.45 - How you can use Xamarin Test Cloud to test your Android apps

It’s hard to write an Android app and it’s even harder to test it. Come and see how Xamarin Test Cloud could help you automate your UI tests and run them on many models and OS versions without having to purchase a single phone.

Speaker 

Peter Bryntesson is a technical evangelist at Microsoft and loves to write code. He has a background as a C++/C# developer for 20+ years. For a couple of years now Xamarin has been a passion and now he actually have that passion as a job! 

19.00 - Painless Persistence with Realm

In a world where users have ever higher expectations from the apps they use, having data always available, even when the device is offline, has become increasingly important.In this talk you will learn how thinking "offline first" not only makes your app architecture better but also result in cleaner code and happier users. I will introduce Realm, a new database for easy persistence, and demonstrate how it enables truly reactive UI's by fitting seamlessly into the standard network stack of Retrofit and RxJava.Finally we will take a look at the new Realm Mobile Platform, which provides real-time synchronization between devices, enabling features previously out of reach for many development teams.BIO:

Speaker

Christian is Team Lead and Android developer at Realm, focused on making the Android SDK the default choice for developers. He has a strong love for clean, approachable code that's fast to boot. | | Prior to Realm, he got a MSc. in Computer Science and built award-winning apps at Trifork. When he's not coding, he enjoys wearing out hiking boots and trying to teach his two small children how to hunt dragons.

events.name: Android Meetup at Fishbrain
events.description:
Our next event will be hosted by Fishbrain at their offices at Jakobsbergsgatan 31. We are really excited to welcome Florina Muntenescu who works at Upday in Berlin. She will be giving two different talks, one introduction to RxJava and one on MV* design patterns for Android. 

Agenda:
17:30 - Doors open. Light food and drinks will be served
18:00 (or maybe a bit earlier) - Presentations starts
- Introduction by Fishbrain
- The ABCs of RxJava by Florina Muntenescu
- A Journey Through MV Wonderland by Florina Muntenescu

Title: The ABCs of RxJava 
Abstract: 
So you have heard about RxJava, maybe checked out some articles, videos or even code - but things are still not that clear!? The aim of this talk is first of all to create the functional reactive programming mindset; to explain what an Observable and a Subscriber are; and to give a bit of insight in the magic of thread handling in RxJava. We will then take a practical example, see how RxJava can be applied and what its advantages are compared to other options.I will end the talk by addressing an important question: how to best proceed to integrate RxJava into an existing app.  

Title: A Journey Through MV Wonderland
Abstract:
Developing an app with a design that changes every few months means that the architecture chosen for the UI has to facilitate change. How do you react fast to UI changes, with minimum amount of code? What pattern is the best for testability? Which pattern gives you most decoupling of classes? MVC, MVP and MVVM are the most popular architecture patterns for implementing user interfaces. Join me on a journey to discover the advantages and disadvantages associated with of each of these and find the best one. We will perform a deep dive into the implementations and tests for each pattern. Learn about the pitfalls that you can expect and how you can avoid them, based on some of the lessons that we have learned.

Speaker bio: 
Florina passionately works at upday as a Senior Android Developer. She has been writing code for more than 7 years, mostly for Android. Florina keeps a strong focus on clean code and UI/UX. Previous work covered payment solutions at payleven and navigation services at Garmin. Florina is  also one of the main contributors to the Android Architectural Blueprints maintained by Google.
events.how_to_find_us: The code for the door is 2003. FishBrain offices can be found on the 5th floor.

events.name: Kotlin presentation from JetBrains
events.description:
We are very happy to announce the first Android Meetup for 2017! 

Doors opens at 17.00, first presentation starts around 17.30.

We will kick off the meetup with a presentation by Fredrik Hyttnäs and Joakim Engström from iZettle, who will give you an introduction on how to make a simple google assistant agent.

This event will have a very special speaker; Svetlana Isakova from JetBrains, who is working as a developer advocate for the Kotlin programming language. 

We're also happy to be hosted again at iZettle. They will provide pizza and beer for everyone, so please RSVP to this event and let them know if you're coming. Specify if you prefer vegetarian food or have any allergies. All attendees will have to be registered their first- and last-name, so make sure your Meetup registration is updated with the correct details.

As usual, we will open the RSVP list a week before the event (Wednesday 15th of February, around lunch). Mark it down in your calendar so you won't miss it! :)

Very welcome!

events.name: Post Google I/O chill
events.description:
It's time for another meetup!

Doors open 17:30, first presentation starts around 18:00

We'll keep it casual this time and have two presentations lined up: Kotlin by Bob Dahlberg and the Android architecture components by Erik Hellman.

This time we'll meet at Citerus who will provide food and drinks for everyone. Please RSVP so we can plan food and beer

Hope to see you there!

events.name: Open Source with Truecaller
events.description:
We are happy to announce a summer get-together! 

Doors opens at 17.00, first presentation starts around 17.30.

Open Source
The focus of this meetup will be open source! We will start the meetup with a presentation by Medo from Truecaller who will present a library the developers at Truecaller have built. Here's what he says:

"We, the engineers at Truecaller, care about threading, A lot!
Sometimes way more then we are supposed to.

That's why we developed a lightweight internal tool inspired by the Actor Pattern, that takes care of all threading for you, in the most simple and natural way.

And now, we are open-sourcing the library, so you too can forget about handling threads and focus more on writing your business logic."

Lightning Talks
We will also allow for lightning talks promoting open source projects you own or contribute too! So take the chance and take 5 minutes to present your library. If your interested send a mail to the group or contact Bob Dahlberg directly.

Hosted by Truecaller
We're also happy to be hosted at Truecaller. They will provide food and beverages for everyone, so please RSVP to this event and let them know if you're coming. Specify if you prefer vegetarian food or have any allergies. All attendees will have to be registered their first- and last-name, so make sure your Meetup registration is updated with the correct details.

RSVP
As usual, we will open the RSVP list a week before the event (Tuesday 8th of August, around lunch). Mark it down in your calendar so you won't miss it! :)

Very welcome!

events.name: Android Meetup at Foo Café
events.description:
We're thrilled to have our next Android Meetup in cooperation with Foo Café 

IMPORTANT!

To sign up for this event you need to register at foocafe.org or here at goto10.se

Abstract

Performance matters and Android Studio 3.0 delivers all-new tools to help diagnose performance issues to keep your apps lean, fast and smooth. Learn about the new Android Profiler, improvements in the APK Analyzer, and a few other tricks in the Android tools.

Speaker 

Wojtek is a Developer Advocate at Google and works closely with the Android Studio team to provide outreach on new Studio and Tools releases and framework features. He enjoys looking for ways to make apps more usable through better development patterns and code optimizations.

events.name: Kotlin x 2
events.description:
Time for the final Android Meetup in Stockholm for 2017. This time we will give 2 talks about Kotlin.

Registration and more information can be found at http://foocafe.org/stockholm/events/1670-kotlin-x-2

events.name: Android Spring Meetup
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 18:45 Robust Android apps with RxJava and Kotlin by Lenny Nilsson

Abstract:
Learn to leverage abstract concepts into a maintainable and reliable codebase.
Also find out how Kotlin and RxJava have evolved Android app development.
With concrete code examples we will discover how every day tasks can be done maintainable, reliable and robust.

Bio:
Lenny Nilsson is a software engineer and Android developer working at Bonnier News. He maintains the Android app with backend systems for an ecosystem of four products; Expressen, SportExpressen, Kvällsposten and GT.

18:50 - 19:45 Use Firebase authentication and Cloud Firestore to easily integrate authentication and realtime sharing in your apps by Oskar Hojwall

Abstract:

Learn how to easily add a sign in solution to your app to secure your API. By using Firebase Authentication it's easy to add username / password authentication as well as third party integrations such as Google or Facebook. Cloud Firestore is Google's new NoSQL cloud database that enables realtime synchronization between clients and offline support.

The talk will feature a presentation about the benefits of these services as well as live coding to see how it can be added to a project.

Bio:

Oskar Höjwall is an Android and backend developer currently working as a consultant at Nordic Choice Hotels. He enjoys working with Kotlin, the Firebase suite of services and any tool that simplifies development.

19:45 - 20:30 Mingle

events.name: Clean Architecture @ Developers Bay
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 18:45 Reactive Clean Architecture on Android by Viktor Nyblom

Abstract:
Working with Android is not always easy and as the codebase grows lifecycle callbacks, threading and new api calls tend to bloat our components until you end up with a big bowl of spaghetti. In this talk, Viktor will explain how to implement Uncle Bob’s Clean Architecture on Android in order to provide you as a developer with a framework for building maintainable, testable apps.
You will learn how to structure your code in a way that makes it easy to add features, easy to integrate unit tests and easy to handle threading

To gain the most from this talk you should at least be somewhat familiar with Kotlin and RxJava

Bio:
Viktor Nyblom is one of the founders of Devies and has been building great experiences for Android users since before the ActionBar. He has been working everything from streaming services and dating apps to AOSP it self

18:50 - 19:45 Followup with Real world example by Jesper Qvarfordt

Abstract:
As a followup on Viktors talk on Clean Architecture, I will show a real world example on how this can be implemented on Android by showing the code of a music app that I published a few weeks ago

Bio:
Jesper Qvarfordt work as the Lead Android developer at BookBeat. He has a strong passion for building robust apps with good architecture

19:45 - 20:30 Mingle

events.name: GDG Android Summer 2018
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 19:00 Data Informed Development & Performance Monitoring by Ivan Dimoski

Abstract:
For a long time now, the product teams have been utilizing the number of tools to help them understand how users interact with their features and apply their observations to improve user's experience.

In this talk, Medo will explain how engineering teams can take upon a similar approach to improve their code quality by defining and tracking engineering metrics, observing and analyzing the data and ultimately taking action upon their learnings to improve the product.

Bio:

Ivan Dimoski a.k.a Medo is a software engineer with 6 years of Android development experience. He moved to Sweden from Macedonia 3 years ago and joined Truecaller to help build an amazing experience for hundreds of millions of users worldwide.

He enjoys cooking and believes that code and meal quality should live up to high standards.

19:10 - 19:50 Modularization - How Hard Can It Be? by Elin Nilsson

Abstract:
Modularizing Android codebases is all the hype these days. It can be as simple as moving a few files, and maybe creating a new build config or two along the way, or it can be much more gruelling. At Spotify, it has meant clearing out years and years of tech debt, re-writing APIs, rethinking the architecture and structure of the application and features that go into it, wrestling with build tools, and then some. This talk will walk you through the Spotify modularization journey: why we got started, how we went about it, what we have learned through the process, and also why you should be thinking about modularizing your code if you haven't already started.

Bio: Elin is an Android developer in the mobile architecture team at Spotify in Stockholm, working on frameworks, libraries and infrastructure for speeding up development. Enjoys API and system design, popcorn, and climbing.

19:50 - 21:00 Mingle Time

events.name: WomAndroid Hackathon Powered by Truecaller
events.description:
WomAndroid Hackathon coming up in less than two weeks!

Where: Trucaller HQ @ Kungsgatan 15
When: 20-21 October

FAST FACTS
- Theme: Sustainability (inspiration from UN 2020 goals)
- Lunch will be served both days (including snacks, coffee, drinks etc. to keep the energy up)
- Kids: Bring them. We will have a nanny present during both days

This will be a weekend of coding, inspiration and a lot of fun!

Why: The main idea with the Womandroid Hackathon is to empower each other, building a network and share knowledge.

The Hackathon:
The theme of the hackathon is sustainability with inspired by UN’s 17 sustainable development goals. Read more: https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/

Think of it as MVP (Minimum Viable Product) product development, presenting ideas, and a lot of coding. And then add the opportunity to meet and work with other people and develop your skills.

Do I need to be an Android Expert?
No. You will be assigned a group where your group members have different levels of experience. What’s required is some kind of knowledge in android development and a big will to learn!

Is that all?
Nope. At the end of the hackathon a jury will look at your project, provide feedback and finally appoint winning teams! There will be neat prizes for the top 3!

Themes of lightning talks:

1. “Remote and local control behavior of android application” by Olga Kuzmina – Android Developer at Truecaller who originates from Russia and thinks Stockholm has a perfect mixture of modern technologies and ancient history.

Abstract:
How to develop new features and keep existing ones in scope of CI&CD process? How to change the behavior of application in required situation? How to improve QA experience?

2. “Who needs inheritance anyway? With Kotlin you don’t! Time to say goodbye to most of the base classes!” by Sevil Guler - Senior consultant at Netlight who likes running, basketball and dogs.

Abstract:
It is not surprising that most of us probably end up working on a project where we are dealing with over-inherited classes such as fragments or activities. We will talk about an alternative to inheritance concept called delegation pattern, which Kotlin supports natively and not surprisingly without requiring any boilerplate.

3. “Know your users, let A/B Testing help you.” by Jinyan Liu – Android Developer at Truecaller who loves BodyCombat and does voluntary work for Stockholm international film festival.

Abstract:
Gather early feedback from your users before safely rolling out new features. Let your users help with decision making. We will look at one A/B Testing case in Truecaller and talk about the details.

4. "Introduction to ARCore" by Kristina Simakova
Kristina is a Senior Software Engineer with 8+ years of experience in Android Application Development, backend and Computer Graphics. She has been developing applications for different industries such as Oil and Gas, Maritime and Construction Industry, FinTech and EdTech. She have been specializing in Android, 3D visualization, VR and AR

*Let us know if there is any specific topic you would like to have as a lightning talk. Depending on the demand we can also increase the number of the lightning talks. If you are interested to give a technical or inspirational talk, please contact us.*

events.name: WomAndroid Afterwork/Tech Talks (Women only)
events.description:
Last month we hosted Womandroid hackathon, an all-woman powered coding weekend, and we now want to invite you for an afterwork and tech talks for those who participated in the event + all those who missed it!

Details

17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.

18.00 - 18.30 Make it Material - A Crash Course in the Visual Language of Android by Marika Driman - Music junkie and Software Developer at Slagkryssaren with a love for Häagen-Dazs, longboarding and Les Mills classes.

Abstract:
It only takes seconds for a user to get a first impression of your app and it will almost entirely be based, not on functionality, but on visual design. How do we make an app look polished and professional? By understanding and applying the fundamentals of Android design and material design principles we can create intuitive and frictionless apps for our users.

18.40 - 19.10 Hold on! Here is Kotlin. One language to rule them all by Sevil Guler - Senior Consultant at Netlight - Helping companies to provide high-quality mobile services to their users. Former at Betsson and Spotify, her strong competence includes Android development with Kotlin and Java, as well as continuous integration and continuous delivery for mobile.

Abstract:
Kotlin is a statically typed programming language for modern multi-platform applications and it’s 100% interoperable with Java. In this presentation, I will talk about the pros and cons of Kotlin from a general aspect, focusing on five Ws: Who, What, Why, When, How. The presentation will end with code samples to show the strength of Kotlin.

19.20 - 19.40 Developer from scratch by Aleksandra Geric - is a life enthusiast, devoted to learning and becoming a better person, thus on a never-ending quest for knowledge and self-improvement. Currently working as a Backend developer at Red Flag.

Abstract:
Becoming a developer in 2018 has some challenges too, but the opportunities are countless. Creating an app just by yourself is now easier than ever before - junior’s view on building your pet project from scratch.

19.40 - 21.30 After Work/Mingle Time

The event is open for women, non-binary and transgender

events.name: Mindfulness for Mobile App Developers by Mikael Kindborg
events.description:
Registration, full details, and the agenda can be found here:
http://www.foocafe.org/stockholm/events/2105-mindfulness-for-mobile-app-developers

Time for Android meetup, this time at FooCafé sponsored by Daresay.

You need to register with FooCafé (NOT HERE PLEASE)!
events.how_to_find_us: Walk from Gullmarsplan or switch to "Tvärbanan 22 mot Sickla", get off at Mårtensdal and you're a block away

events.name: GDG Android Spring Meetup 2019
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 18:45 Creating reactive UI with LiveData by Oskar Höjwall

Abstract:
Learn how you can incorporate LiveData from Android's Architecture Components into your app to see how easy it can be to ensure your data is always up to date without having to worry about lifecycle management or memory leaks.

Bio:
Oskar Höjwall is a freelancing Android and backend developer working as a consultant at Ramirent. He's passionate about Kotlin and is always tinkering with the latest technologies and loves to share what he finds.

18:50 - 19:50 Kotlin Coroutines on Android: How to say goodbye to threading and callback hell by Sevil Guler

Abstract:
Coroutines is full of possibilities and offers new ways of working with background tasks, resulting in more simple, elegant and clean code. In this event we will talk about coroutines with the focus of understanding how to get rid of threads and callback patterns. Get ready to be amazed with the new world of clean coding that coroutines opens up to everyone.
PS: This talk will be in introduction level.

Bio:
Sevil is senior consultant at Netlight - Helping companies to provide high-quality mobile services to their users. Her strong competence includes Android development with Kotlin and Java, as well as continuous integration and continuous delivery for mobile.

19:50 - 20:30 Mingle

events.name: Android Open Space Conference
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 18:30 Open space planning
18:30 - 19:00 OS 1
19:10 - 19:40 OS 2
20:00 - 20:30 OS 3

This time we're going to have a lot of fun trying out Open Space Technology. If you're unfamiliar with OS then have a look here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M_jhcvCYBbg

We have a couple of rooms to spread out in so we can have multiple parallel sessions. Anyone interested in Android are welcome to participate. It doesn't matter it you are a beginner or expert, all are welcome. We'll start the OS planning 18:00 sharp, so please be on time if you want to pitch a session.

Ps. If you signed up and can't join, please give up your spot at least 24h before the event so the next in line can plan their week. Ds

events.name: GDG Android Summer Meetup 2019
events.description:
17.30 - 18.00 Doors open, food and drinks served, mingle.
18:00 - 18:45 Using Kotlin Native for a shared codebase by Erik Manberger

Abstract: Erik will talk about how Kotlin Native can be used to share code between projects, more specifically between Android and iOS projects.

Bio: Erik Manberger is an Android developer working at Isotop. He has a passion for new technology and have been a member of the Stockholm Android meetup group since 2014.

18:50 - 19:35 What’s new in Android with a deeper dive into Jetpack Compose by Ann-Sofi

Abstract: Ann-Sofi will start with an overview of some of the new features, tools and restrictions presented at Google I/O before deeper into the new declarative toolkit for building UI on Android: Jetpack Compose.

Bio: Ann-Sofi Åhn is an Android developer working at Isotop where they build apps for, among others, Sveriges Radio. She likes to live dangerously and will try the latest Android beta or Android Studio canary…even if that means that she can’t pay her bills since BankID keeps failing.

19:35 - 20:30 Mingle

organizers.name: Bob D.
organizers.bio: I love to try different languages, patterns and concepts to improve my thinking and ability to build and design reactive, resilient and scalable applications.

group_profile.intro: Android GDE and author of "Android Programming: Pushing the limits".
